Screenwriter Scott Marshall Smith wrote Men of Honor based on real events that occurred with diver Carl Brashear when he was part of the U.S. Navy, but the intimidating character played by actor Robert DeNiro (Billy Sunday) was entirely a fictional creation that brings together personalities Brashear met several men who during his military career. The film began in 1994 and, due to its theme, went through a long and unusual. The story was submitted to the Department of Defense, then forwarded to the Pentagon and finally reached the hands of the Secretary of Defense for approval. With the cooperation of the Navy guaranteed, the filmmakers found at the base Columbia River in Washington, the perfect place for the recordings. All actors in the production were trained diving. The scenes on the seabed were made in a tank with more than one million liters, an aircraft hangar built in Long Beach. Carl Brashear (Cuba Gooding Jr) does not let anything get in your way. Son of a farmer in Kentucky, Carl leaves her parents' home in search of a better life. Joins the Navy and want to become a diver's elite search and rescue division. BiIIy Sunday (Robert DeNiro), naval officer and training instructor, will not, however, know Carl nor his ambitions. Submit it to the worst endurance in trying to make it fail and give up. With coexistence, mutual respect is born that will lead them to fight together to defend the honor and protect their lives.
